Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Rapid Calculation of Earthquake Damage and Repair Costs for High-Performance Building Design
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is that structural engineers will be enabled to design high-performance buildings that have minimal damage in earthquakes. Using the software tool created in this project would fundamentally change the way in which a structural engineer develops the initial design for a building. By enabling engineers to enhance their understanding of building performance, they will be able to design buildings for higher seismic performance and will thus improve the resilience of buildings in future earthquakes. There is a large potential new market for this software, as it can eventually be used by every one of the approximately 10,000 structural engineers designing buildings in the Western United States, and the tens of thousands of engineers working worldwide in regions with earthquake hazards.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop technology to rapidly estimate the structural behavior during an earthquake and also provide a rapid estimation of the inventory of components in a building. This rapid autopopulation will then enable efficient calculations that predict the damage, the repair costs, and the repair time for a building when it experiences an earthquake. The company's method for rapid estimation of structural responses will utilize principles of engineering mechanics, applied to estimating response of a structure whose properties are not fully specified. The method for rapid estimation of building contents will learn from users' updates to the company's initial predictions. The proposed statistical model will enable the company to study this question, and deploy a model that allows real-time and user-specific refinements in a scalable manner.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A major outcome of this project was a statistical model to predict displacements and accelerations in reinforced concrete frame buildings when they are subjected to earthquakes, calibrated using an extensive set of structural analyses produced by this project. Qualitatively speaking, the extensive analyses produced a training set of data so that we can rapidly predict structural responses when customers use our software for similar buildings. With this work established the feasibility of this approach for producing reasonable response predictions, and implemented the predictive model in our software. A second key outcome of the project was an algorithm for estimating the types and quantities of components present in a building, as a function of building properties such as year of design, occupancy type, etc. Further, we developed algorithms to estimate the strengths of anchored equipment that would have been required by building codes, so that we can better estimate the damageability of those components.

The intellectual merit of this project is that it developed technology to rapidly estimate structural demands and the inventory of components in a building that has only been schematically designed. This rapid autopopulation enables calculations to predict the damage, repair costs and recovery time that would occur if the building was subjected to an earthquake. Our method for rapid estimation of structural responses utilizes principles of engineering mechanics, but applied in a domain where academic research does not focus (i.e., estimating response of a structure whose properties are not fully specified).

The broader impact of the project is that it enables structural engineers to use our software when designing high-performance buildings that minimize damage in earthquakes. This will change the way in which structural engineers develop initial designs for buildings. By enabling design of buildings for higher seismic performance, our tool will improve the resilience of building tenants after future earthquakes. 

 


Last Modified: 07/03/2016
Modified by: Curt Haselton
